{"step_by_step_thinking": "The presence of bacitracin-resistant colonies of gram-positive cocci with surrounding areas of clear hemolysis suggests the presence of Group B Streptococcus (GBS) infection. GBS is a common cause of neonatal sepsis and can be transmitted vertically during childbirth. The most appropriate intervention to decrease vertical transmission of GBS is to administer intrapartum antibiotics. This reduces the risk of transmission to the newborn. Therefore, the correct answer is B. Administer ampicillin intrapartum.", "answer_choice": "B"}
